intro: [WRONG START] Illcecebrum alsinifolium, commonly known as the creeping bentgrass, is a low-growing perennial grass species native to Europe and parts of Asia. It features slender, often prostrate stems that spread along the ground, forming dense mats. The leaves are narrow, slightly hairy, and have a distinctive blue-green color. Its small, inconspicuous flowers are arranged in spikelets, typical of the Poaceae family. This plant is adapted to moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and along stream banks.
